sections: Enter for your chance to win this milestone 2020 C8 Corvette.
Corvette officially rolled off the assembly line
in Flint, Michigan - a Polo White convertible with red interior – and was followed by another 299 just like it for the 1953 model year. Now, 67 years later, the 1.75 millionth
is slated to roll off the assembly line in Bowling Green, Ky. in mid-to-late August.
The one millionth Corvette (a 1992 model) and the 1.5 millionth
(a 2009 model), both white with red interior convertibles, reside at the National Corvette Museum, becoming famous years after their ‘birth’ when they
sinkhole inside the Museum. The one millionth Corvette has since been restored by General Motors and both cars can be viewed in the Museum’s Skydome.
The 1.75 millionth Corvette, an Arctic White Coupe with Adrenaline Red interior, will only temporarily call the National Corvette Museum its home as it will be used in a

“We are appreciative of Chevrolet for aligning the production of one of our Corvette raffle cars so that it would become this milestone in production,” shared Dr. Sean Preston, President and CEO of the National Corvette Museum. “It’s exciting that in just 11 years Bowling Green Assembly has produced 250,000 Corvettes. No other sports car can claim that kind of production volume or enthusiast following.”
The Corvette will be raffled on Friday, September 4 at 3 p.m. CT as part of the

and features the Z51 performance package, 3LT equipment group, 5-trident spoke machined-face sterling silver aluminum wheels, engine appearance package, front lift adjustable height with memory and more. The car will be delivered via the
program, also referred to as option code R8C when ordering a new Corvette, which provides a red carpet V.I.P. experience for the winner and up to three accompanying guests.
“While you do not have to be a raffle winner to pick-up your Corvette from the Museum, we always look forward to celebrating with those who won their car from us,” added Sean.
Another perk for both raffle winners and other Museum ‘R8C’ Delivery program participants is the opportunity to drive a
C8 on track at the NCM Motorsports

Park. The facility features a 3.15 mile road course, and customers can pilot one of the track-owned Corvettes for four touring laps in a lead-follow format. Visitors to Bowling Green can also participate in the Corvette Touring program, as well as many other driving programs available at the Motorsports Park. Of course, after driving a new Corvette on-track they’ll be itching to own one, too, and the Museum’s raffle program is a great way to take a chance at ownership.

“The Museum has been raffling Corvettes for over 20 years, welcoming new enthusiasts to the family in the process,” said Sean. “We are appreciative of those who support our raffle program through ticket purchases as it is one of the primary fundraisers for the Museum.”

The National Corvette Museum is a 501c3 nonprofit foundation. Tickets for the raffle are $200 each and the raffle is limited to 1,500 tickets. Tickets can be acquired via a secure, barcoded mail order form available online at
or purchased at the Museum while visiting. The Museum is open daily, 8 a.m. to 5 p.m. CT and is located at I-65 exit 28 in Bowling Green, Kentucky. Plan your visit at
. The Motorsports Park is also open daily, but advanced reservations are highly recommended. Check out their event calendar of upcoming driving events at motorsportspark.org.
